metadata.titleEn: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (eddy covariance system of desert station, 2023)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the desert station eddy covariance system (EC) in the downstream reaches of the Heihe integrated observatory network from January 1 to December 31 in 2023. The site (100.9872° E, 42.1135° N) was located in the Ejina Banner in Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. The elevation is 1054 m. The EC was installed at a height of 4.7 m, and the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the type of eddy covariance was closed-path (CPEC200).
The raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Eddypro post-processing software, including the spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. The observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC): class 1-3 (high quality), class 4-6 (good), class 7-8 (poor, better than gap filling data), class9 (rejected). In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data collected before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 10% of the 30 min raw record. There were 48 records per day, and the missing data were replaced with -6999. Suspicious data were marked in red. 
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xls format. Detailed information can be found in the suggested references.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) and Liu et al. (2023).

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What does 'eddy covariance system' mean in the context of data collection for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange?
Definition.Answer: An eddy covariance system is a method used to measure and calculate vertical turbulent fluxes within the atmosphere. It is commonly used in ecosystem research for observing the exchange of energy, water vapor, carbon dioxide, and methane between the surface and the atmosphere. The method involves using instruments to record high-frequency data, which are then processed to determine fluxes over a specified period.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'quality control procedure' in the context of handling observational datasets?
Definition.Answer: A quality control procedure in the context of handling observational datasets refers to a systematic process of ensuring the accuracy and reliability of data collected. This includes data collection, processing, archiving, and sharing, as well as steps like removing erroneous data points, correcting delays, rotating coordinates, and applying density corrections to ensure the dataset is robust and usable for analysis.

Comparison.Question: How do the data processing steps for eddy covariance systems in arid regions compare to those used in oasis–desert systems?
Comparison.Answer: In arid regions, eddy covariance data processing includes steps such as outlier removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, and density correction, similar to the procedures in oasis–desert systems where long-term observations are crucial. Both systems emphasize quality evaluation of flux values and the significance of understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data collection challenges faced by inland river basins compared to oasis–desert systems under climate change conditions?
Comparison.Answer: Inland river basins face challenges such as drying rivers and lakes, land desertification, and dust storms, while oasis–desert systems need to maintain ecological and economic stability. Both environments require attention to sustainable development and long-term observation to manage their respective climate-induced challenges.

Interpretation.Question: How do the challenges of ecological degradation in arid regions influence the design and implementation of observational datasets in oasis–desert systems?
Interpretation.Answer: The challenges of ecological degradation, such as drying rivers and land desertification, necessitate comprehensive observational datasets that include long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon flux measurements along with auxiliary hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil data. This indicates that data collection methodologies are designed to capture complex interactions and trends over time, which are crucial for understanding and mitigating environmental degradation in these sensitive regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the necessity of maintaining a balance between oasis and desert systems for sustainable development in arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Maintaining balance between oasis and desert systems is critical for sustainable development due to the oasis's role as a core ecological landscape and economic foundation in arid regions. Oases support the majority of the population and play a crucial role in maintaining ecological stability and agricultural productivity.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it important to understand energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve carbon peaking and carbon neutrality goals, protect ecological stability, and support sustainable socioeconomic development in these areas.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the challenges faced by inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas that affect the ecological environment?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face challenges such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms, which contribute to ecological environment degradation.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using Eddypro software for processing eddy covariance data on the accuracy and reliability of the observed flux measurements in arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using Eddypro software for processing eddy covariance data involves multiple steps such as coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, and quality assessment. These processing techniques can improve the accuracy and reliability of flux measurements by correcting for measurement errors and ensuring that only high-quality data is used for analysis. This is particularly important in arid regions where precise measurements of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges are crucial for understanding the oasis-desert interactions and maintaining ecological balance.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of long-term observational datasets on the management and sustainability of oasis-desert ecosystems, particularly in the face of climate change?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Long-term observational datasets provide critical insights into the dynamics of oasis-desert ecosystems by capturing temporal variations and trends in energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes. These datasets enable researchers to assess the impacts of climate change and human activities on these ecosystems, facilitating informed management decisions. They are essential for achieving sustainable development goals by identifying patterns that can guide interventions to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems and ensure ecological security.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind collecting long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to understand the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, which is crucial for achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality goals, supporting ecological security, and sustainable development of oases.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to establish a comprehensive observation network using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers in arid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important to establish such an observation network to provide quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, recognize oasis–desert interactions, and protect ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases through long-term observations.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of integrating hydrometeorological data alongside flux measurements in datasets pertaining to oasis–desert areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The purpose of integrating hydrometeorological data alongside flux measurements is to supplement the datasets with comprehensive environmental parameters, which are essential for understanding the interactions within oasis–desert systems and addressing ecological and climatic challenges in these regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in processing the 10Hz raw data from an eddy covariance system to obtain usable flux data in arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The 10Hz raw data from an eddy covariance system is processed using Eddypro software to generate 30-minute average data. The main steps include despiking, time delay correction, double coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, sonic virtual temperature correction, and WPL correction. Quality evaluation is conducted based on atmospheric stability and turbulent similarity characteristics. Data is filtered by removing erroneous data, excluding data 1 hour before and after precipitation, and discarding records where more than 10% of raw data is missing within a 30-minute interval.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the key methodologies for collecting auxiliary hydrometeorological data in oasis-desert regions to support flux measurements?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Key methodologies for collecting auxiliary hydrometeorological data include using automatic weather stations to measure radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles. These measurements are typically averaged over 10-minute periods, and groundwater table data is also collected to provide comprehensive support for flux measurements.

Enablement.Question: What data processing and quality control procedures enable the accurate measurement of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems?
Enablement.Answer: The data processing and quality control procedures involve steps such as data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing. Specifically, the raw data from eddy covariance systems are processed using Eddypro software, which includes steps like wild point removal, time lag correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density correction. Quality evaluation of flux values focuses on atmospheric stability and turbulence characteristics.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or challenges must be addressed to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems for sustainable development?
Enablement.Answer: Maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems requires addressing ecological challenges such as river and lake drying, natural vegetation degradation, land desertification, and dust storms. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange is crucial for achieving carbon neutrality and supporting ecological and socioeconomic stability in these regions.

Expectation.Question: Why might the quality of data from eddy covariance systems in oasis–desert areas vary significantly, and what are the expected outcomes of implementing rigorous data processing techniques?
Expectation.Answer: The quality of data from eddy covariance systems can vary due to factors such as instrument errors, environmental conditions, and data loss. Implementing rigorous data processing techniques, such as those involving Eddypro software, aims to improve data quality by removing outliers, correcting delays, and applying coordinate rotations and frequency response corrections. This is expected to result in more reliable datasets that can better support studies of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems.

Expectation.Question: What expectations exist for the role of oasis–desert areas in the global carbon cycle, and how does the data collection methodology support these expectations?
Expectation.Answer: Oasis–desert areas are expected to act as carbon sinks, significantly impacting the carbon balance of arid regions and playing a role in the global carbon cycle. The data collection methodology, which includes long-term measurements of carbon fluxes using eddy covariance systems, supports these expectations by providing detailed insights into carbon exchange processes, helping to quantify the contribution of oasis–desert systems to the carbon cycle.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of data processing techniques, such as Eddypro software, in ensuring the accuracy of datasets related to energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The data processing techniques, including Eddypro software, are crucial for ensuring dataset accuracy by implementing steps like outlier removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, and frequency response adjustments. These methods help maintain data integrity and quality, essential for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in arid regions.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how can the integration of hydrometeorological data and vegetation parameters enhance the understanding of oasis–desert interactions and their implications on ecological stability?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating hydrometeorological data and vegetation parameters can significantly enhance the understanding of oasis–desert interactions by providing a comprehensive view of the energy, water, and carbon dynamics. This integration helps in examining the impacts of these interactions on ecological stability and supports sustainable development efforts in arid regions.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data quality can be ensured when using eddy covariance systems in desert environments.
Assertion.Answer: Data quality in eddy covariance systems is ensured through specific data processing steps, including outlier removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density correction. Additionally, data quality is evaluated based on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics. Quality flags are assigned to the data, indicating different levels of data quality.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how observational datasets from oasis–desert systems can inform sustainable development strategies.
Assertion.Answer: Observational datasets from oasis–desert systems provide quantitative insights into energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, which are critical for understanding the ecological interactions in these areas. This understanding supports the development of strategies for ecological security and sustainable development by maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems and achieving goals such as carbon peaking and neutrality.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the methods used to ensure the quality and accuracy of data collected by eddy covariance systems in arid regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: The field involves using Eddypro software to process raw 10Hz data into 30-minute intervals. Quality assurance steps include removing outliers, correcting time delays, coordinate rotation, and applying frequency response and density corrections. Quality evaluation is performed through tests of atmospheric stability and turbulent similarity, and data are screened to remove errors, precipitation effects, and high missing data rates.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges faced in data collection and management in oasis–desert ecosystems, particularly regarding long-term observations.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges include ecological degradation such as river and lake drying, vegetation degradation, and increased desertification. Managing these issues requires maintaining comprehensive datasets over time, which is difficult due to environmental conditions. Long-term data collection is crucial for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, which are essential for achieving sustainable development in these regions.
